title: French music awards Les Flammes shines light on criticized 'urban music' label
summary: The Les Flammes ceremony, to be held on Thursday evening, aims to highlight the diversity of pop music.

title: Glide bombs: Russia's 'ultimate weapon' or a sign of Ukraine's under-equipment?
summary: Russia's military seems to have found a way to upset the balance between firepower and defensive capabilities with these inexpensively improved Soviet-era bombs.

title: In EU speech, Macron says Europe is 'mortal' and 'can die'
summary: A few weeks ahead of the June European elections, the French president outlined his vision of Europe in a speech at the Sorbonne university in Paris.

title: Debate on youth violence: 'Repression is a popular idea, but it's a failure'
summary: Not only is the portrayal of violent and uncontrollable youth a longstanding political myth, but the many repressive policies adopted over the past two centuries have further destabilized vulnerable young people and their families.

title: French Palme d'Or winner Laurent Cantet dies
summary: His agent Isabelle de la Patelliere said the filmmaker died of illness in Paris.

title: US campus protests for Gaza turn into electoral trap for Biden
summary: Demonstrations and sit-ins against the war in Gaza are increasing at universities across the country. Joe Biden risks alienating both part of the youth and a segment of the Jewish vote.

title: Dubai underwater: climate change has amplified historic rains
summary: The torrential rains that killed 24 people in the UAE and Oman on April 15 and 16 were 10% to 40% more intense as a result of climate change, according to a World Weather Attribution study.

title: Harvey Weinstein's sex crime conviction overturned by New York court
summary: The New York court found the trial judge unfairly allowed testimony against Weinstein based on allegations that weren't part of the case.

title: Israeli hostage families fear they are being forgotten
summary: More than six months after October 7, 130 people, mostly Israelis, are still being held by Hamas in the Gaza Strip. Negotiations for their release appear to be at a complete standstill, compounding a simmering political crisis.

title: 'For Meloni's right, anti-fascism is a divisive factor'
summary: The cancellation of writer Antonio Scurati's speech for the April 25 celebrations that mark the anniversary of liberation from Nazism and Fascism in Italy is seen as an act of censorship, reawakening a quarrel over the country's history.

title: US reinstates open access internet rules rescinded under Trump
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission on Thursday restored 'net neutrality' rules that prevent broadband internet providers from favoring some sites and apps over others.

title: Thousands of flights canceled in France due to planned strike
summary: A decision by the biggest air traffic controller union SNCTA on Wednesday to withdraw their strike call came too late to avoid mass cancelations.

title: Haiti's transitional council sworn in after PM Henry's resignation
summary: The 9-member Transitional Presidential Council has replaced former prime minister Ariel Henry, who resigned as promised in March, to lead gang violence-stricken Haiti.  Their main task is to get the country ready for elections in 2026, the first since 2016.

title: Paris's Moulin Rouge windmill blades collapse overnight
summary: The wings of the iconic French landmark fell off overnight for reasons not yet known. No injuries were reported.

title: 2024 EU elections: French far right ditches candidate who made racist remarks
summary: In 2017, Saidali Boina Hamissi referred to Comorians as 'vermin' and 'cockroaches.' The government has also accused him of being 'sexist,' a conspiracy theorist and a Putin 'admirer.'

title: Former resident of Nir Oz kibbutz lifts veil on conditions of her children's detention in Gaza
summary: In her newly published book, Hadas Kalderon revisits the captivity of her daughter, Sahar, 17, and son, Erez, 12, who were held hostage by Hamas for almost two months.

title: French 'The Voice' star says he 'simulated suicide' to scare girlfriend
summary: Kendji Girac was seriously injured by a gunshot this week. Investigators have ruled out anyone else being involved.

title: Nestlé destroys two million bottles of Perrier over bacterial contamination
summary: In an order dated April 19, the company received formal notice to 'immediately suspend' operations at one of its seven water extraction sites in Vergèze, in southern France.

title: Les Flammes 2024: Aya Nakamura dominates and wins top awards
summary: Meanwhile, Gazo was named Male Artist of the Year and SCH won the prestigious award for the Best Concert for his performance at the Vélodrome in Marseille.

title: Guatemala prosecutors raid offices of Save the Children over alleged child abuse
summary: The raid follows reports in local media that Guatemalan prosecutors asked the Texas attorney general's office for help investigating the alleged trafficking of Guatemalan children on the southern US border.

title: Lausanne's Institute of Technology, 'saturated' with French students, tightens admissions
summary: Faced with an unprecedented influx of international students, mainly from France, one of Europe's top engineering schools, moved to tighten its admission requirements for 2025.

title: For Princess Madoki 'waacking' is freedom
summary: Dancer-choreographer Josépha Madoki is a major figure of 'waacking,' a dance style from the 1970s US gay community. Discovering it in 2005, she soon came to embody its festive energy. She will perform at the Musée d'Orsay, in Paris, from April 26 to 28.

title: China warns Blinken relations with US could go on a 'downward spiral'
summary: The US top diplomat Antony Blinken paid his second visit to the country in less than a year on Friday, with China's foreign minister warning the US not to 'trample on China's red line' following pressure on its economy.

title: Columbia University drops deadline for dismantling pro-Palestinian protest camp
summary: Police have carried out large-scale arrests in universities across the US, at times using chemical irritants and tasers to disperse protests over Israel's war with Hamas.

title: Macron's grand ambitions for Europe ahead of EU elections
summary: In a speech in Paris on Thursday, the French president called for a stronger EU defense and proposed doubling the EU budget to pave the way for a 'powerful Europe.'

title: Global wine consumption kept declining in 2023
summary: According to the International Organization of Vine and Wine, consumption fell by 2.6% year-on-year to 221 million hectoliters. On the production side, indicators are also negative.

title: Our selection of the five best brioches in Ile-de-France
summary: Buttery and nicely puffed, these fluffy delights work wonders at breakfast or afternoon tea.

title: Situation is tense at Paris' Sciences Po over Pro-Palestinian protests
summary: The provisional administrator of the elite school had called in police to break up a student vigil to support Gazans on Wednesday, sowing confusion among academic staff. The occupation was renewed the next evening by around 50 students.

title: Lunch in Paris? 15 (delicious) set menus from 20 to 30 euros
summary: Smoked eel tacos or veggie mezze, fantastic pizzas or Korean dishes: Le Monde picked 15 places in Paris to enjoy a seasonal menu without breaking the bank.

title: At Donald Trump's trial, sex, the press, and politics mix
summary: Thursday's testimony of the former head of the 'National Enquirer' tabloid highlighted the partnership that developed between him and Trump during the 2016 presidential campaign.

title: British police charge two men after Channel migrant deaths
summary: One man from Sudan was charged with assisting unlawful immigration, and he and another man from South Sudan were charged with entering the UK illegally.

title: China calls Germany spying claims 'pure fabrication'
summary: This week, four Germans were arrested on suspicions of spying for China, including the assistant to a far-right member of the European Parliament.

title: US will withdraw some troops from Chad, says Pentagon
summary: The United States will withdraw part of its 100 troops present in Chad, days after began discussions with Niger on withdrawing 1,000 troops from that country.

title: From de Gaulle to Macron, Le Monde's complicated relationship with French presidents
summary: France's 'paper of reference' has had mixed relations with each of the eight presidents of the Fifth Republic, trying to balance its role as a counter-power and the delicate task of expressing a position ahead of elections.

title: Paris 2024: All the details on the opening ceremony's security perimeters
summary: Paris police presented the traffic bans, restricted areas, and other measures that will be put in place starting on July 18. Two security perimeters will be set up around the Seine river.

title: Russia arrests Forbes journalist over Bucha massacre posts
summary: Sergei Mingazov, a journalist for the Russian edition of Forbes magazine, faces up to 10 years in prison for 'reposting a publication about the events in Bucha,' a site of Russian massacres in Ukraine, according to his lawyer.

title: Burkina Faso suspends BBC and Voice of America
summary: The West African country suspended the radio networks for two weeks, after they aired and published an NGO report critical of Burkina Faso's army, as the latest of many attacks on international media in the country.

title: French government holds its breath ahead of credit rating updates
summary: Friday evening, Moody's and Fitch will issue opinions on France's credit rating. President Macron's government fears a reprimand from the rating agencies, which could have political consequences.

title: Scotland's Yousaf cancels major speech as job under threat
summary: First Minister Humza Yousaf was due to speak on Scottish independence, but changed plans as the opposition prepares to lodge a vote of no confidence, following his decision to end a power-sharing agreement with the Greens.

title: Winner chosen in annual Paris baguette 'Grand Prix'
summary: Xavier Netry becomes 31st winner of the competition, meaning his bakery will be a supplier for the Elysée Palace over the next year.

title: Germany's far-right AfD party is mired in scandal
summary: After a series of electoral successes in 2023, the party has faced a series of major scandals. Most recently, its top candidate in the European elections is under judicial investigation for his ties to China and Russia.

title: Paris 2024: France plans 6,000 police to secure Olympic torch arrival
summary: The deployment of extra officers was announced though 'no specified threat' to the event has been identified.

title: France's influence on the European political scene is waning
summary: After playing a leading role in the EU's handling of the Covid-19 crisis and the war in Ukraine, Paris is now increasingly isolated within the EU.

title: France and Germany sign deal to co-develop 'tank of the future'
summary: The French and German defense ministers agreed to jointly develop a new battle tank platform with cutting-edge AI and laser weapons technology.

title: Laurent Cantet, humanist filmmaker who subtly wove social issues and romantic stakes
summary: Winner of the Palme d'Or at Cannes in 2008 with 'The Class,' the director also distinguished himself by turning the corporate world into a cinematic stage with 'Human Resources' in 2000. He died on Thursday, April 25, at the age of 63.

title: Joe Biden says he's 'happy to debate' Donald Trump
summary: Speaking to radio host Howard Stern, the US president said he would be 'happy' to debate his presumptive Republican opponent ahead of the November election.

title: EU toughens rules for online fast fashion retailer Shein
summary: Shein, a Chinese-founded fashion platform that has been the target of allegations of environmental and human exploitation, joined a list of large platforms that the EU's Digital Services Act subjects to stricter safety rules.

title: Mayors worry their police officers will be 'sucked into' Olympics security arrangements
summary: To reassure mayors, especially those in tourist areas worried about the massive influx of Parisians fleeing the Olympic Games this summer, the Interior Ministry has said neither police nor gendarmes will be allowed to take time off.

title: China's auto industry cradle aims to reinvent itself around EVs
summary: In the 1990s and 2000s, French automakers had a strong presence in Wuhan. In recent years, they have been joined by the many Chinese brands now involved in the rapid electrification of the sector.

title: Greece hands Olympic flame to 2024 Paris Games hosts
summary: The Paris Olympics flame was formally handed to French organizers in the all-marble stadium where the first modern Games were held in Athens in 1896.
